docTitle.titlePart:
Mr VVILLIAM
SHAKESPEARES
COMEDIES,
HISTORIES, &
TRAGEDIES.
Publiſhed according to the True Originall Copies.

titlePage.docImprint: London : Printed by Isaac Iaggard, and Ed. Blount [at the charges of W. Iaggard, Ed. Blount, I. Smithweeke, and W. Aspley]., 1623.

foliation.p: Numbering peculiarities: 1st count: p.50 misnumbered 58; p.59 misnumbered 51; p.86 misnumbered 88; p.153 misnumbered 151; p.161 misnumbered] 163; p.164 misnumbered 162; p. 165 misnumbered 163; p. 189 misnumbered 187; p. 249 misnumbered 251; p.250 misnumbered 252; p. 265 misnumbered 273 -- 2nd count: p.37 misnumbered 39 in some copies; p.89 misnumbered 91; p. 90 misnumbered 92 -- 3rd count: p.165-166 numbered 167 and 168 respectively; p. 216 numbered 218 -- 5th count: p. 279 misnumbered 259; p. 282 misnumbered 280; p.308 misnumbered 38; p. 379 misnumbered 389; p. 399 misnumbered 993.

collation.p: The signatures varies between sources, with the most commonly cited being Hinman's and West's: 1. Hinman: πA⁶ (πA1+1) [πB²], ²A-2B⁶ 2C² a-g⁶ χgg⁸ h-v⁶ x⁴ χ1.2 [para.]-2[para.]⁶ 3[para]¹ aa-ff⁶ gg² Gg⁶ hh⁶ kk-bbb⁶; 2. West: πA⁶ (πA1+1, πA5+1.2)²A-2B⁶ 2C² a-g⁶ ²g⁸ h-v⁶ x⁴ 'gg3.4' (±'gg3') [para.]-2[para.]⁶ 3[para]¹ 2a-2f⁶ 2g² 2G⁶ 2h⁶ 2k-2v⁶ x⁶ 2y-3b⁶.
Mis-signed leaves: a3 mis-signed Aa3; ³gg1 mis-signed Gg; nn1-nn2 mis-signed Nn and Nn2 and oo1 mis-signed Oo.
"The life and death of King Iohn" begins new pagination on leaf a1 recto; "The tragedy of Coriolanus" begins new pagination on leaf aa1 recto.

supportDesc.condition: Lacks A1, the letterpress frontispiece entitled "To the reader". The title page is trimmed and mounted, with a section of the mount towards the foot of the leaf mutilated resulting in the loss of some the Droechout imprint at the bottom left hand corner of the portrait and the central section of an early MS note. For a full condition report, including a full survey of damage and repairs, please contact Rare Books.

layout.p: Colophon reads: "Printed at the charges of W. Iaggard, Ed. Blount, I. Smithweeke, and W. Aspley. 1623.".
Editors’ dedication signed: Iohn Heminge. Henry Condell.

decoDesc.decoNote: With an engraved title-page portrait of the author signed: "Martin- Droeshout: sculpsit· London.". The plate exists in 2 states: 1. The earlier state has lighter shading generall ; 2. Later state has heavier shading, especially around the collar, and minor differences particularly with the jawline and moustache. The vast majority of surviving copies have the plate in the second state which has led some scholars to conclude that the earlier state was a proof. The portrait in this copy is the second state.

additions.p: Two MS verses on first endpaper verso: 1. 9 lines of verse by an unknown author, first line reads "An active swain to make a leap was seen". 2. A copy of Ben Jonson’s printed "To the Reader"; MS note on t.p. (mutilated) appears to read "Honest [Shakes]peare". Minor annotations on leaf 2n4 (Macbeth). All in an early English hand, presumably added after leaving the Library.

bindingDesc.p: Seventeenth-century (1624) English (Oxford) smooth calf. Bound for the Bodleian Library by William Wildgoose, with evidence of two cloth ties, red sprinkled edge. Formerly chained, with evidence of chain staple at the head of the upper cover. Remains of paper label at the head of the spine. Enclosed in 20th century book box by Maltby of Oxford. See S. Gibson in Original Bodleian Copy of First Folio, p. 12-13. One of four items sent out on 17th February 1624 for binding by Wildgoose containing printed waste from a copy of Cicero’s "De Officiis, et al." [Deventer: Richard Pafraet, between 1480 and 1485] as paste-downs. For more information on this work see: Bod. Inc. Cat., C-322.

origin.p: For further details on the printing of this item see Hinman, Charleton. The printing and proof-reading of the First Folio of Shakespeare: Oxford, 1963.

acquisition.p: Acquired by the Bodleian in 1623, presumably in sheets. It was sent out to William Wildgoose on 17 February 1624 for binding (see: Library Records e.258, fol. 48r) and upon its return chained in Duke Humfrey at shelfmark S 2.17 Art. It is listed in the Bodleian’s 1635 catalogue of printed books but was gone by the publication of the next catalogue in 1674, replaced by the newer Third Folio (1664). There is no explicit reference in Library Records to the disposal of this copy, but there is a record of a sale of "superfluous library books" to Richard Davis, a bookseller in Oxford, in 1664 for the sum of £24.

After leaving the Bodleian this copy entered the collection of Richard Turbutt of Ogston Hall, Derbyshire at some point in the early 18th century. It stayed in the family’s possession until 1906, when it was reacquired by the Bodleian for the sum of £3000, raised by public subscription. For a full discussion of the rediscovery and purchase of this copy see: F. Madan, G. M. R. Turbutt and S. Gibson, The Original Bodleian Copy of the First Folio of Shakespeare (theTurbutt Shakespeare) (Oxford, 1905)
For a full discussion of this copy and the digital version see http://shakespeare.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/ and West and Rasmussen (2011), 31.

person.persName: Euphronius, an ambassador from Antony to Caesar
Mardian, a eunuch, attendant on Cleopatra
Octavia, sister to Caesar and wife to Antony
Roman (Silius), an officer in Ventidius's army

div.head:
THE TRAGEDIE OF
Anthonie, and Cleopatra.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.l: NAy, but this dotage of our Generals
Ore‑flowes the measure: those his goodly eyes
That o're the Files and Musters of the Warre,
Haue glow'd like plated Mars:
Now bend, now turne
The Office and Deuotion of their view
Vpon a Tawny Front. His Captaines heart,
Which in the scuffles of great Fights hath burst
The Buckles on his brest, reneages all temper,
And is become the Bellowes and the Fan
To coole a Gypsies Lust.
sp.stage:
Flourish. Enter Anthony, Cleopatra, her Ladies, the
Traine, with Eunuchs fanning her.
sp.l: Looke where they come:
Take but good note, and you shall see in him
(The triple Pillar of the world) transform'd
Into a Strumpets Foole. Behold and see.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: If it be Loue indeed, tell me how much.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There's beggery in the loue that can be reckon'd

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Ile set a bourne how farre to be belou'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l:
Then must thou needes finde out new Heauen,
new Earth.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Newes (my good Lord) from Rome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Grates me, the summe.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Nay heare them Anthony.
Fuluia perchance is angry: Or who knowes,
If the scarse‑bearded Cæsar haue not sent
His powrefull Mandate to you. Do this, or this;
Take in that Kingdome, and Infranchise that:
Perform't, or else we damne thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How, my Loue?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Perchance? Nay, and most like:
You must not stay heere longer, your dismission
Is come from Cæsar, therefore heare it Anthony
Where's Fuluias Processe? (Cæsars I would say) both?
Call in the Messengers: As I am Egypts Queene,
Thou blushest Anthony, and that blood of thine
Is Cæsars homager: else so thy cheeke payes shame,
When shrill‑tongu'd Fuluia scolds. The Messengers.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let Rome in Tyber melt, and the wide Arch
Of the raing'd Empire fall: Heere is my space,
Kingdomes are clay: Our dungie earth alike
Feeds Beast as Man; the Noblenesse of life
Is to do thus: when such a mutuall paire,
And such a twaine can doo't, in which I binde
One paine of punishment, the world to weete
We stand vp Peerelesse.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Excellent falshood:
Why did he marry Fuluia, and not loue her?
Ile seeme the Foole I am not. Anthony will be himselfe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But stirr'd by Cleopatra.
Now for the loue of Loue, and her soft houres,
Let's not confound the time with Conference harsh;
There's not a minute of our liues should stretch
Without some pleasure now. What sport to night?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Heare the Ambassadors.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Fye wrangling Queene:
Whom euery thing becomes, to chide, to laugh,
To weepe: who euery passion fully striues
To make it selfe (in Thee) faire, and admir'd.
No Messenger but thine, and all alone, to night
Wee'l wander through the streets, and note
The qualities of people. Come my Queene,
Last night you did desire it. Speake not to vs.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Is Cæsar with Anthonius priz'd so slight?

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.l: Sir sometimes when he is not Anthony,
He comes too short of that great Property
Which still should go with Anthony.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p:
I am full sorry, that hee approues the common
Lyar, who thus speakes of him at Rome; but I will hope
of better deeds to morrow. Rest you happy.

div.head: [Act 1, Scene 2]
div.stage:
Enter Enobarbus, Lamprius, a Southsayer, Rannius, Lucilli­
us, Charmian, Iras, Mardian the Eunuch,
and Alexas.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
L. Lord
Alexas, sweet Alexas, most any thing Alexas,
almost most absolute Alexas, where's the Soothsayer
that you prais'd so to'th'Queene? Oh that I knewe this
Husband, which you say, must change his Hornes with
Garlands.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Soothsayer.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: Your will?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Is this the Man? Is't you sir that know things?

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p:
In Natures infinite booke of Secrecie, a little I
can read.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Shew him your hand.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: Bring in the Banket quickly: Wine enough,
Cleopatra's health to drinke.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Good sir, giue me good Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.l: I make not, but foresee.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Pray then, foresee me one.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.l: You shall be yet farre fairer then you are.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: He meanes in flesh.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: No, you shall paint when you are old.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Wrinkles forbid.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Vex not his prescience, be attentiue.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Hush.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.l: You shall be more belouing, then beloued.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I had rather heate my Liuer with drinking.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Nay, heare him.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Good now some excellent Fortune: Let mee
be married to three Kings in a forenoone, and Widdow
them all: Let me haue a Childe at fifty, to whom Herode
of Iewry may do Homage. Finde me to marrie me with
Octauius Cæsar, and companion me with my Mistris.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.l: You shall out‑liue the Lady whom you serue.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Oh excellent, I loue long life better then Figs.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p:
You haue seene and proued a fairer former for­
tune, then that which is to approach.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Then belike my Children shall haue no names:
Prythee how many Boyes and Wenches must I haue.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p:
If euery of your wishes had a wombe, & fore­
tell euery wish, a Million.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Out Foole, I forgiue thee for a Witch.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
You thinke none but your sheets are priuie to
your wishes.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Nay come, tell Iras hers.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Wee'l know all our Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
Mine, and most of our Fortunes to night, shall
be drunke to bed.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p: There's a Palme presages Chastity, if nothing els.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
E'ne as the o're‑flowing Nylus presageth Fa­
mine.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p: Go you wilde Bedfellow, you cannot Soothsay.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Nay, if an oyly Palme bee not a fruitfull Prog­
nostication, I cannot scratch mine eare. Prythee tel her
but a worky day Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: Your Fortunes are alike.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p: But how, but how, giue me particulars.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: I haue said.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p: Am I not an inch of Fortune better then she?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Well, if you were but an inch of fortune better
then I: where would you choose it.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p: Not in my Husbands nose.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Our worser thoughts Heauens mend.

sp.speaker: Alexas.
sp.p:
Come, his Fortune, his Fortune. Oh let him
mary a woman that cannot go, sweet Isis, I beseech thee,
and let her dye too, and giue him a worse, and let worse
follow worse, till the worst of all follow him laughing to
his graue, fifty‑fold a Cuckold. Good Isis heare me this
Prayer, though thou denie me a matter of more waight:
good Isis I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p:
Amen, deere Goddesse, heare that prayer of the
people. For, as it is a heart‑breaking to see a handsome
man loose‑Wiu'd, so it is a deadly sorrow, to beholde a
foule Knaue vncuckolded: Therefore deere Isis keep de­
corum, and Fortune him accordingly.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Lo now, if it lay in their hands to make mee a
Cuckold, they would make themselues Whores, but
they'ld doo't.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p: Hush, heere comes Anthony.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Not he, the Queene.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Saue you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p: No Lady.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Was he not heere?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: No Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: He was dispos'd to mirth, but on the sodaine
A Romane thought hath strooke him.
Enobarbus?

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Seeke him, and bring him hither: wher's Alexias?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Heere at your seruice.
My Lord approaches.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: We will not looke vpon him:
Go with vs.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: Fuluia thy Wife,
First came into the Field.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Against my Brother Lucius?

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: I: but soone that Warre had end,
And the times state
Made friends of them, ioynting their force 'gainst Cæsar,
Whose better issue in the warre from Italy,
Vpon the first encounter draue them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well, what worst.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: The Nature of bad newes infects the Teller.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: When it concernes the Foole or Coward: On.
Things that are past, are done, with me. 'Tis thus,
Who tels me true, though in his Tale lye death,
I heare him as he flatter'd.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Labienus (this is stiffe‑newes)
Hath with his Parthian Force
Extended Asia: from Euphrates his conquering
Banner shooke, from Syria to Lydia,
And to Ionia, whil'st⸺

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Anthony thou would'st say.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Oh my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Speake to me home,
Mince not the generall tongue, name
Cleopatra as she is call'd in Rome:
Raile thou in Fuluia's phrase, and taunt my faults
With such full License, as both Truth and Malice
Haue power to vtter. Oh then we bring forth weeds,
When our quicke windes lye still, and our illes told vs
Is as our earing: fare thee well awhlle awhile .

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: At your Noble pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: From Scicion how the newes? Speake there.

sp.speaker: 1. Mes.
sp.l: The man from Scicion,
Is there such an one?

sp.speaker: 2. Mes.
sp.l: He stayes vpon your will.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let him appeare:
These strong Egyptian Fetters I must breake,
Or loose my selfe in dotage.
sp.stage: Enter another Messenger with a Letter.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: 3. Mes.
sp.l: Fuluia thy wife is dead.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where dyed she.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: In Scicion, her length of sicknesse,
With what else more serious,
Importeth thee to know, this beares.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Forbeare me
There's a great Spirit gone, thus did I desire it:
What our contempts doth often hurle from vs,
We wish it ours againe. The present pleasure,
By reuolution lowring, does become
The opposite of it selfe: she's good being gon,
The hand could plucke her backe, that shou'd her on.
I must from this enchanting Queene breake off,
Ten thousand harmes, more then the illes I know
My idlenesse doth hatch.
How now Enobarbus.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: What's your pleasure, Sir?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I must with haste from hence.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Why then we kill all our Women. We see how
mortall an vnkindnesse is to them, if they suffer our de­
parture death's the word.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Vnder a compelling an occasion, let women die.
It were pitty to cast them away for nothing, though be­
tweene them and a great cause, they should be esteemed
nothing. Cleopatra catching but the least noyse of this,
dies instantly: I haue seene her dye twenty times vppon
farre poorer moment: I do think there is mettle in death,
which commits some louing acte vpon her, she hath such
a celerity in dying.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: She is cunning past mans thought.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Alacke Sir no, her passions are made of nothing
but the finest part of pure Loue. We cannot cal her winds
and waters, sighes and teares: They are greater stormes
and Tempests then Almanackes can report. This cannot
be cunning in her; if it be, she makes a showre of Raine
as well as Ioue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Would I had neuer seene her.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Oh sir, you had then left vnseene a wonderfull
peece of worke, which not to haue beene blest withall,
would haue discredited your Trauaile.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fuluia is dead.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fuluia is dead.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Fuluia?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Dead.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Why sir, giue the Gods a thankefull Sacrifice:
when it pleaseth their Deities to take the wife of a man
from him, it shewes to man the Tailors of the earth: com­
forting therein, that when olde Robes are worne out,
there are members to make new. If there were no more
Women but Fuluia, then had you indeede a cut, and the
case to be lamented: This greefe is crown'd with Conso­
lation, your old Smocke brings foorth a new Petticoate,
and indeed the teares liue in an Onion, that should water
this sorrow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The businesse she hath broached in the State,
Cannot endure my absence.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
And the businesse you haue broach'd heere can­
not be without you, especially that of Cleopatra's, which
wholly depends on your abode.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more light Answeres:
Let our Officers
Haue notice what we purpose. I shall breake
The cause of our Expedience to the Queene,
And get her loue to part. For not alone
The death of Fuluia, with more vrgent touches
Do strongly speake to vs: but the Letters too
Of many our contriuing Friends in Rome,
Petition vs at home. Sextus Pompeius
Haue giuen the dare to Cæsar, and commands
The Empire of the Sea. Our slippery people,
Whose Loue is neuer link'd to the deseruer,
Till his deserts are past, begin to throw
Pompey the great, and all his Dignities
Vpon his Sonne, who high in Name and Power,
Higher then both in Blood and Life, stands vp
For the maine Souldier. Whose quality going on,
The sides o'th'world may danger. Much is breeding,
Which like the Coursers heire, hath yet but life,
And not a Serpents poyson. Say our pleasure,
To such whose places vnder vs, require
Our quicke remoue from hence.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: I shall doo't.

div.head: [Act 1, Scene 3]
div.stage: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Alexas, and Iras.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I did not see him since.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: See where he is,
Whose with him, what he does:
I did not send you. If you finde him sad,
Say I am dauncing: if in Myrth, report
That I am sodaine sicke. Quicke, and returne.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Madam, me thinkes if you did loue him deerly,
You do not hold the method, to enforce
The like from him.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What should I do, I do not?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: In each thing giue him way, crosse him in nothing.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Thou teachest like a foole: the way to lose him.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Tempt him not so too farre. I wish forbeare,
In time we hate that which we often feare.
But heere comes Anthony.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I am sicke, and sullen.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I am sorry to giue breathing to my purpose.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Helpe me away deere Charmian, I shall fall,
It cannot be thus long, the sides of Nature
Will not sustaine it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now my deerest Queene.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Pray you stand farther from mee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I know by that same eye ther's some good news.
What sayes the married woman you may goe?
Would she had neuer giuen you leaue to come.
Let her not say 'tis I that keepe you heere,
I haue no power vpon you: Hers you are.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The Gods best know.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Oh neuer was there Queene
So mightily betrayed: yet at the first
I saw the Treasons planted.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Cleopatra.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Why should I thinke you can be mine, & true,
(Though you in swearing shake the Throaned Gods)
Who haue beene false to Fuluia?
Riotous madnesse,
To be entangled with those mouth‑made vowes,
Which breake themselues in swearing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Most sweet Queene.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Nay pray you seeke no colour for your going,
But bid farewell, and goe:
When you sued staying,
Then was the time for words: No going then,
Eternity was in our Lippes, and Eyes,
Blisse in our browes bent: none our parts so poore,
But was a race of Heauen. They are so still,
Or thou the greatest Souldier of the world,
Art turn'd the greatest Lyar.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How now Lady?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I would I had thy inches, thou should'st know
There were a heart in Egypt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Heare me Queene:
The strong necessity of Time, commands
Our Seruicles a‑while: but my full heart
Remaines in vse with you. Our Italy,
Shines o're with ciuill Swords; Sextus Pompeius
Makes his approaches to the Port of Rome,
Equality of two Domesticke powers,
Breed scrupulous faction: The hated growne to strength
Are newly growne to Loue: The condemn'd Pompey,
Rich in his Fathers Honor, creepes apace
Into the hearts of such, as haue not thriued
Vpon the present state, whose Numbers threaten,
And quietnesse growne sicke of rest, would purge
By any desperate change: My more particular,
And that which most with you should safe my going,
Is Fuluias death.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Though age from folly could not giue me freedom
It does from childishnesse. Can Fuluia dye?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She's dead my Queene.
Looke heere, and at thy Soueraigne leysure read
The Garboyles she awak'd: at the last, best,
See when, and where shee died.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O most false Loue!
Where be the Sacred Violles thou should'st fill
With sorrowfull water? Now I see, I see,
In Fuluias death, how mine receiu'd shall be.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Quarrell no more, but bee prepar'd to know
The purposes I beare: which are, or cease,
As you shall giue th'aduice. By the fire
That quickens Nylus slime, I go from hence
Thy Souldier, Seruant, making Peace or Warre,
As thou affects.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Cut my Lace, Charmian come,
But let it be, I am quickly ill, and well,
So Anthony loues.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My precious Queene forbeare,
And giue true euidence to his Loue, which stands
An honourable Triall.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: So Fuluia told me.
I prythee turne aside, and weepe for her,
Then bid adiew to me, and say the teares
Belong to Egypt. Good now, play one Scene
Of excellent dissembling, and let it looke
Like perfect Honor.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You'l heat my blood no more?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: You can do better yet: but this is meetly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now by Sword.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: And Target. Still he mends.
But this is not the best. Looke prythee Charmian,
How this Herculean Roman do's become
The carriage of his chase.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ile leaue you Lady.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Courteous Lord, one word:
Sir, you and I must part, but that's not it:
Sir, you and I haue lou'd, but there's not it:
That you know well, something it is I would:
Oh, my Obliuion is a very Anthony,
And I am all forgotten.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But that your Royalty
Holds Idlenesse your subiect, I should take you
For Idlenesse it selfe.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: 'Tis sweating Labour,
To beare such Idlenesse so neere the heart
As Cleopatra this. But Sir, forgiue me,
Since my becommings kill me, when they do not
Eye well to you. Your Honor calles you hence,
Therefore be deafe to my vnpittied Folly,
And all the Gods go with you. Vpon your Sword
Sit Lawrell victory, and smooth successe
Be strew'd before your feete.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let vs go.
Come: Our separation so abides and flies,
That thou reciding heere, goes yet with mee;
And I hence fleeting, heere remaine with thee.
Away.

div.head: [Act 1, Scene 4]
div.stage:
Enter Octauius reading a Letter, Lepidus,
and their Traine.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: You may see Lepidus, and henceforth know,
It is not Cæsars Naturall vice, to hate
One great Competitor. From Alexandria
This is the newes: He fishes, drinkes, and wastes
The Lampes of night in reuell: Is not more manlike
Then Cleopatra: nor the Queene of Ptolomy
More Womanly then he. Hardly gaue audience
Or vouchsafe to thinke he had Partners. You
Shall finde there a man, who is th'abstracts of all faults,
That all men follow.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: I must not thinke
There are, euils enow to darken all his goodnesse:
His faults in him, seeme as the Spots of Heauen,
More fierie by nights Blacknesse; Hereditarie,
Rather then purchaste: what he cannot change,
Then what he chooses.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: You are too indulgent. Let's graunt it is not
Amisse to tumble on the bed of Ptolomy,
To giue a Kingdome for a Mirth, to sit
And keepe the turne of Tipling with a Slaue,
To reele the streets at noone, and stand the Buffet
With knaues that smels of sweate: Say this becoms him
(As his composure must be rare indeed,
Whom these things cannot blemish) yet must Anthony
No way excuse his foyles, when we do beare
So great waight in his lightnesse. If he fill'd
His vacancie with his Voluptuousnesse,
Full surfets, and the drinesse of his bones,
Call on him for't. But to confound such time,
That drummes him from his sport, and speakes as lowd
As his owne State, and ours, 'tis to be chid:
As we rate Boyes, who being mature in knowledge,
Pawne their experience to their present pleasure,
And so rebell to iudgement.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Heere's more newes.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Thy biddings haue beene done, & euerie houre
Most Noble Cæsar, shalt thou haue report
How 'tis abroad. Pompey is strong at Sea,
And it appeares, he is belou'd of those
That only haue feard Cæsar: to the Ports
The discontents repaire, and mens reports
Giue him much wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: I should haue knowne no lesse,
It hath bin taught vs from the primall state
That he which is was wisht, vntill he were:
And the ebb'd man,
Ne're lou'd, till ne're worth loue,
Comes fear'd, by being lack'd. This common bodie,
Like to a Vagabond Flagge vpon the Streame,
Goes too, and backe, lacking the varrying tyde
To rot it selfe with motion.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Cæsar I bring thee word,
Menacrates and Menas famous Pyrates
Makes the Sea serue them, which they eare and wound
With keeles of euery kinde. Many hot inrodes
They make in Italy, the Borders Maritime
Lacke blood to thinke on't, and flush youth reuolt,
No Vessell can peepe forth: but 'tis as soone
Taken as seene: for Pompeyes name strikes more
Then could his Warre resisted.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Anthony,
Leaue thy lasciuious Vassailes. When thou once
Was beaten from Medena, where thou slew'st
Hirsius, and Pausa Consuls, at thy heele
Did Famine follow, whom thou fought'st against,
(Though daintily brought vp) with patience more
Then Sauages could suffer. Thou did'st drinke
The stale of Horses, and the gilded Puddle
Which Beasts would cough at. Thy pallat thē them did daine
The roughest Berry, on the rudest Hedge.
Yea, like the Stagge, when Snow the Pasture sheets,
The barkes of Trees thou brows'd. On the Alpes,
It is reported thou did'st eate strange flesh,
Which some did dye to looke on: And all this
(It wounds thine Honor that I speake it now)
Was borne so like a Soldiour, that thy cheeke
So much as lank'd not.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: 'Tis pitty of him.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Let his shames quickely
Driue him to Rome, 'tis time we twaine
Did shew our selues i'th'Field, and to that end
Assemble me immediate counsell, Pompey
Thriues in our Idlenesse.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: To morrow Cæsar,
I shall be furnisht to informe you rightly
Both what by Sea and Land I can be able
To front this present time.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Til which encounter, it is my busines too. Farwell.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Farwell my Lord, what you shal know mean time
Of stirres abroad, I shall beseech you Sir
To let me be partaker.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Doubt not sir, I knew it for my Bond.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Charmian.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Ha, ha, giue me to drinke Mandragora.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Why Madam?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: That I might sleepe out this great gap of time:
My Anthony is away.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You thinke of him too much.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O 'tis Treason.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Madam, I trust not so.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Thou, Eunuch Mardian?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What's your Highnesse pleasure?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Not now to heare thee sing. I take no pleasure
In ought an Eunuch ha's: Tis well for thee,
That being vnseminar'd, thy freer thoughts
May not flye forth of Egypt. Hast thou Affections?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes gracious Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not in deed Madam, for I can do nothing
But what in deede is honest to be done:
Yet haue I fierce Affections, and thinke
What Venus did with Mars.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Oh Charmion:
Where think'st thou he is now? Stands he, or sits he?
Or does he walke? Or is he on his Horse?
Oh happy horse to beare the weight of Anthony!
Do brauely Horse, for wot'st thou whom thou moou'st,
The demy Atlas of this Earth, the Arme
And Burganet of men. Hee's speaking now,
Or murmuring, where's my Serpent of old Nyle,
(For so he cals me:) Now I feede my selfe
With most delicious poyson. Thinke on me
That am with Phœbus amorous pinches blacke,
And wrinkled deepe in time. Broad‑fronted Cæsar,
When thou was't heere aboue the ground, I was
A morsell for a Monarke: and great Pompey
Would stand and make his eyes grow in my brow,
There would he anchor his Aspect, and dye
With looking on his life.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Soueraigne of Egypt, haile.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: How much vnlike art thou Marke Anthony?
Yet comming from him, that great Med'cine hath
With his Tinct gilded thee.
How goes it with my braue Marke Anthonie?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Last thing he did (deere Quene)
He kist the last of many doubled kisses
This Orient Pearle. His speech stickes in my heart.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Mine eare must plucke it thence.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Good Friend, quoth he:
Say the firme Roman to great Egypt sends
This treasure of an Oyster: at whose foote
To mend the petty present, I will peece
Her opulent Throne, with Kingdomes. All the East,
(Say thou) shall call her Mistris. So he nodded,
And soberly did mount an Arme‑gaunt Steede,
Who neigh'd so hye, that what I would haue spoke,
Was beastly dumbe by him.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What was he sad, or merry?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Like to the time o'th'yeare, between yͤ extremes
Of hot and cold, he was nor sad nor merrie.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Oh well diuided disposition: Note him,
Note him good Charmian, 'tis the man; but note him.
He was not sad, for he would shine on those
That make their lookes by his. He was not merrie,
Which seem'd to tell them, his remembrance lay
In Egypt with his ioy, but betweene both.
Oh heauenly mingle! Bee'st thou sad, or merrie,
The violence of either thee becomes,
So do's it no mans else. Met'st thou my Posts?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I Madam, twenty seuerall Messengers.
Why do you send so thicke?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Who's borne that day, when I forget to send
to Anthonie, shall dye a Begger. Inke and paper Char­
mian. Welcome my good Alexas. Did I Charmian, e­
uer loue Cæsar so?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Oh that braue Cæsar!

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Be choak'd with such another Emphasis,
Say the braue Anthony.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: The valiant Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: By Isis, I will giue thee bloody teeth
If thou with Cæsar Paragon againe:
My man of men.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: By your most gracious pardon,
I sing but after you.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: My Sallad dayes,
When I was greene in iudgement, cold in blood,
To say, as I saide then. But come, away,
Get me Inke and Paper,

he shall haue euery day a seuerall greeting, or Ile vnpeo­
ple Egypt.

div.head: [Act 2, Scene 1]
div.stage:
Enter Pompey, Menecrates, and Menas, in
warlike manner.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: If the great Gods be iust, they shall assist
The deeds of iustest men.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.p:
Know worthy Pompey, that what they do de­
lay, they not deny.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Whiles we are sutors to their Throne, decayes
the thing we sue for.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: We ignorant of our selues,
Begge often our owne harmes, which the wise Powres
Deny vs for our good: so finde we profit
By loosing of our Prayers.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: I shall do well:
The people loue me, and the Sea is mine;
My powers are Cressent, and my Auguring hope
Sayes it will come to'th'full. Marke Anthony
In Egypt sits at dinner, and will make
No warres without doores. Cæsar gets money where
He looses hearts: Lepidus flatters both,
Of both is flatter'd: but he neither loues,
Nor either cares for him.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Cæsar and Lepidus are in the field,
A mighty strength they carry.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Where haue you this? 'Tis false.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: From Siluius, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: He dreames: I know they are in Rome together
Looking for Anthony: but all the charmes of Loue,
Salt Cleopatra soften thy wand lip,
Let Witchcraft ioyne with Beauty, Lust with both,
Tye vp the Libertine in a field of Feasts,
Keepe his Braine fuming. Epicurean Cookes,
Sharpen with cloylesse sawce his Appetite,
That sleepe and feeding may prorogue his Honour,
Euen till a Lethied dulnesse⸺
How now Varrius?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: This is most certaine, that I shall deliuer:
Marke Anthony is euery houre in Rome
Expected. Since he went from Egypt, 'tis
A space for farther Trauaile.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: I could haue giuen lesse matter
A better eare. Menas, I did not thinke
This amorous Surfetter would haue donn'd his Helme
For such a petty Warre: His Souldiership
Is twice the other twaine: But let vs reare
The higher our Opinion, that our stirring
Can from the lap of Egypts Widdow, plucke
The neere Lust‑wearied Anthony.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: I cannot hope,
Cæsar and Anthony shall well greet together;
His Wife that's dead, did trespasses to Cæsar,
His Brother wan'd vpon him, although I thinke
Not mou'd by Anthony.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: I know not Menas,
How lesser Enmities may giue way to greater,
Were't not that we stand vp against them all:
'Twer pregnant they should square between themselues,
For they haue entertained cause enough
To draw their swords: but how the feare of vs
May Ciment their diuisions, and binde vp
The petty difference, we yet not know:
Bee't as our Gods will haue't; it onely stands
Our liues vpon, to vse our strongest hands
Come Menas.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Good Enobarbus, 'tis a worthy deed,
And shall become you well, to intreat your Captaine
To soft and gentle speech.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: I shall intreat him
To answer like himselfe: if Cæsar moue him,
Let Anthony looke ouer Cæsars head,
And speake as lowd as Mars. By Iupiter,
Were I the wearer of Anthonio's Beard,
I would not shaue't to day.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: 'Tis not a time for priuate stomacking.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Euery time serues for the matter that is then
borne in't.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: But small to greater matters must giue way.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Not if the small come first.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Your speech is passion: but pray you stirre
No Embers vp. Heere comes the Noble Anthony.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: And yonder Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If we compose well heere, to Parthia:
Hearke Ventidius.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: I do not know Mecenas, aske Agrippa.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Noble Friends:
That which combin'd vs was most great, and let not
A leaner action rend vs. What's amisse,
May it be gently heard. When we debate
Our triuiall difference loud, we do commit
Murther in healing wounds. Then Noble Partners,
The rather for I earnestly beseech,
Touch you the sowrest points with sweetest tearmes,
Nor curstnesse grow to'th'matter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis spoken well:
Were we before our Armies, and to fight,
I should do thus.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Welcome to Rome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thanke you.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Sit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sit sir.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I learne, you take things ill, which are not so:
Or being, concerne you not.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: I must be laught at, if or for nothing, or a little, I
Should say my selfe offended, and with you
Chiefely i'th'world. More laught at, that I should
Once name you derogately: when to sound your name
It not concern'd me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My being in Egypt Cæsar, what was't to you?

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: No more then my reciding heere at Rome
Might be to you in Egypt: yet if you there
Did practise on my State, your being in Egypt
Might be my question.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How intend you, practis'd?

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: You may be pleas'd to catch at mine intent,
By what did heere befall me. Your Wife and Brother
Made warres vpon me, and their contestation
Was Theame for you, you were the word of warre.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You do mistake your busines, my Brother neuer
Did vrge me in his Act: I did inquire it,
And haue my Learning from some true reports
That drew their swords with you, did he not rather
Discredit my authority with yours,
And make the warres alike against my stomacke,
Hauing alike your cause. Of this, my Letters
Before did satisfie you. If you'l patch a quarrell,
As matter whole you haue to make it with,
It must not be with this.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
You praise your selfe, by laying defects of iudge­
ment to me: but you patcht vp your excuses.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Not so, not so:
I know you could not lacke, I am certaine on't,
Very necessity of this thought, that I
Your Partner in the cause 'gainst which he fought,
Could not with gracefull eyes attend those Warres
Which fronted mine owne peace. As for my wife,
I would you had her spirit, in such another,
The third oth'world is yours, which with a Snaffle,
You may pace easie, but not such a wife.

sp.speaker: Enobar.
sp.p:
Would we had all such wiues, that the men
might go to Warres with the women.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: So much vncurbable, her Garboiles (Cæsar)
Made out of her impatience: which not wanted
Shrodenesse of policie to: I greeuing grant,
Did you too much disquiet, for that youmust,
But say I could not helpe it.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: I wrote to you, when rioting in Alexandria you
Did pocket vp my Letters: and with taunts
Did gibe my Misiue out of audience.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, he fell vpon me, ere admitted, then:
Three Kings I had newly feasted, and did want
Of what I was i'th'morning: but next day
I told him of my selfe, which was as much
As to haue askt him pardon. Let this Fellow
Be nothing of our strife: if we contend
Out of our question wipe him.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.p:
You haue broken the Article of your oath,
which you shall neuer haue tongue to charge me with.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Soft Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No Lepidus, let him speake,
The Honour is Sacred which he talks on now,
Supposing that I lackt it: but on Cæsar,
The Article of my oth.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.p:
To lend me Armes, and aide when I requir'd
them, the which you both denied.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Neglected rather:
And then when poysoned houres had bound me vp
From mine owne knowledge, as neerely as I may,
Ile play the penitent to you. But mine honesty,
Shall not make poore my greatnesse, nor my power
Worke without it. Truth is, that Fuluia,
To haue me out of Egypt, made Warres heere,
For which my selfe, the ignorant motiue, do
So farre aske pardon, as befits mine Honour
To stoope in such a case.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: 'Tis Noble spoken.

sp.speaker: Mece.
sp.l: If it might please you, to enforce no further
The griefes betweene ye: to forget them quite,
Were to remember: that the present neede,
Speakes to attone you.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Worthily spoken Mecenas.

sp.speaker: Enobar.
sp.p:
Or if you borrow one anothers Loue for the
instant, you may when you heare no more words of
Pompey returne it againe: you shall haue time to wrangle
in, when you haue nothing else to do.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Thou art a Souldier, onely speake no more.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
That trueth should be silent, I had almost for­
got.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l:
You wrong this presence, therefore speake no
more.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: Go too then: your Considerate stone.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: I do not much dislike the matter, but
The manner of his speech: for't cannot be,
We shall remaine in friendship, our conditions
So diffring in their acts. Yet if I knew,
What Hoope should hold vs staunch from edge to edge
Ath'world: I would persue it.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Giue me leaue Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Speake Agrippa.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.p:
Thou hast a Sister by the Mothers side, admir'd
Octauia: Great Mark Anthony is now a widdower.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.p:
Say not, say Agrippa; if Cleopater heard you, your
proofe were well deserued of rashnesse.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p:
I am not marryed Cæsar: let me heere Agrippa
further speake.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: To hold you in perpetuall amitie,
To make you Brothers, and to knit your hearts
With an vn‑slipping knot, take Anthony,
Octauia to his wife: whose beauty claimes
No worse a husband then the best of men: whose
Vertue, and whose generall graces, speake
That which none else can vtter. By this marriage,
All little Ielousies which now seeme great,
And all great feares, which now import their dangers,
Would then be nothing. Truth's would be tales,
Where now halfe tales be truth's: her loue to both,
Would each to other, and all loues to both
Draw after her. Pardon what I haue spoke,
For 'tis a studied not a present thought,
By duty ruminated.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Will Cæsar speake?

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Not till he heares how Anthony is toucht,
With what is spoke already.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: What power is in Agrippa,
If I would say Agrippa, be it so,
To make this good?

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: The power of Cæsar,
And his power, vnto Octauia.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: May I neuer
(To this good purpose, that so fairely shewes)
Dreame of impediment: let me haue thy hand
Further this act of Grace: and from this houre,
The heart of Brothers gouerne in our Loues,
And sway our great Designes.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: There's my hand:
A Sister I bequeath you, whom no Brother
Did euer loue so deerely. Let her liue
To ioyne our kingdomes, and our hearts, and neuer
Flie off our Loues againe.

sp.speaker: Lepi.
sp.l: Happily, Amen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I did not think to draw my Sword 'gainst Pompey,
For he hath laid strange courtesies, and great
Of late vpon me. I must thanke him onely,
Least my remembrance, suffer ill report:
At heele of that, defie him.

sp.speaker: Lepi.
sp.l: Time cals vpon's,
Of vs must Pompey presently be sought,
Or else he seekes out vs.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Where lies he?

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: About the Mount‑Mesena.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: What is his strength by land?

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Great, and increasing:
But by Sea he is an absolute Master.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: So is the Fame,
Would we had spoke together. Hast we for it,
Yet ere we put our selues in Armes, dispatch we
The businesse we haue talkt of.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: With most gladnesse,
And do inuite you to my Sisters view,
Whether straight Ile lead you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Let vs Lepidus not lacke your companie.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Noble Anthony, not sickenesse should detaine
me.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.p: Welcome from Ægypt Sir.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Halfe the heart of Cæsar, worthy Mecenas. My
honourable Friend Agrippa.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.p: Good Enobarbus.

sp.speaker: Mece.
sp.p:
We haue cause to be glad, that matters are so
well disgested: you staid well by't in Egypt.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
I Sir, we did sleepe day out of countenaunce:
and made the night light with drinking.

sp.speaker: Mece.
sp.p:
Eight Wilde‑Boares rosted whole at a break­
fast, and but twelue persons there. Is this true?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
This was but as a Flye by an Eagle: we had much
more monstrous matter of Feast, which worthily deser­
ued noting.

sp.speaker: Mecenas.
sp.p:
She's a most triumphant Lady, if report be
square to her.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
When she first met Marke Anthony, she purst
vp his heart vpon the Riuer of Sidnis.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.p:
There she appear'd indeed: or my reporter de­
uis'd well for her.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: I will tell you,
The Barge she sat in, like a burnisht Throne
Burnt on the water: the Poope was beaten Gold,
Purple the Sailes: and so perfumed that
The Windes were Loue‑sicke.
With them the Owers were Siluer,
Which to the tune of Flutes kept stroke, and made
The water which they beate, to follow faster;
As amorous of their strokes. For her owne person,
It beggerd all discription, she did lye
In her Pauillion, cloth of Gold, of Tissue,
O're‑picturing that Venus, where we see
The fancie out‑worke Nature. On each side her,
Stood pretty Dimpled Boyes, like smiling Cupids,
With diuers coulour'd Fannes whose winde did seeme,
To gloue the delicate cheekes which they did coole,
And what they vndid did.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Oh rare for Anthony.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Her Gentlewoman, like the Nereides,
So many Mer‑maides tended her i'th'eyes,
And made their bends adornings. At the Helme.
A seeming Mer‑maide steeres: The Silken Tackle,
Swell with the touches of those Flower‑soft hands,
That yarely frame the office. From the Barge
A strange inuisible perfume hits the sense
Of the adiacent Wharfes. The Citty cast
Her people out vpon her: and Anthony
Enthron'd i'th'Market‑place, did sit alone,
Whisling to'th'ayre: which but for vacancie,
Had gone to gaze on Cleopater too,
And made a gap in Nature.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Rare Egiptian.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Vpon her landing, Anthony sent to her,
Inuited her to Supper: she replyed,
It should be better, he became her guest:
Which she entreated, our Courteous Anthony,
Whom nere the word of no woman hard speake,
Being barber'd ten times o're, goes to the Feast;
And for his ordinary, paies his heart,
For what his eyes eate onely.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Royall Wench:
She made great Cæsar lay his Sword to bed,
He ploughed her, and she cropt.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: I saw her once
Hop forty Paces through the publicke streete,
And hauing lost her breath, she spoke, and panted,
That she did make defect, perfection,
And breathlesse powre breath forth.

sp.speaker: Mece.
sp.l: Now Anthony, must leaue her vtterly.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Neuer he will not:
Age cannot wither her, nor custome stale
Her infinite variety: other women cloy
The appetites they feede, but she makes hungry,
Where most she satisfies. For vildest things
Become themselues in her, that the holy Priests
Blesse her, when she is Riggish.

sp.speaker: Mece.
sp.l: If Beauty, Wisedome, Modesty, can settle
The heart of Anthony: Octauia is
A blessed Lottery to him.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p:
Let vs go. Good Enobarbus, make your selfe
my guest, whilst you abide here.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Humbly Sir I thanke you.

div.head: [Act 2, Scene 3]
div.stage: Enter Anthony, Cæsar, Octauia betweene them.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: The world, and my great office, will
Sometimes deuide me from your bosome.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p:
All which time, before the Gods my knee shall
bowe my prayers to them for you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Goodnight Sir. My Octauia
Read not my blemishes in the worlds report:
I haue not kept my square, but that to come
Shall all be done byth'Rule: good night deere Lady:
Good night Sir.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.p: Goodnight.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Now sirrah: you do wish your selfe in Egypt?

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p:
Would I had neuer come from thence, nor you
thither.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If you can, your reason?

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.l: I see it in my motion: haue it not in my tongue,
But yet hie you to Egypt againe.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p:
Say to me, whose Fortunes shall rise higher
Cæsars or mine?

sp.speaker: Soot.
sp.l: Cæsars. Therefore (oh Anthony) stay not by his side
Thy Dæmon that thy spirit which keepes thee, is
Noble, Couragious, high vnmatchable,
Where Cæsars is not. But neere him, thy Angell
Becomes a feare: as being o're‑powr'd, therefore
Make space enough betweene you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Speake this no more.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.l: To none but thee no more but: when to thee,
If thou dost play with him at any game,
Thou art sure to loose: And of that Naturall lucke,
He beats thee 'gainst the oddes. Thy Luster thickens,
When he shines by: I say againe, thy spirit
Is all affraid to gouerne thee neere him:
But he alway 'tis Noble.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Get thee gone:
Say to Ventigius I would speake with him.
He shall to Parthia, be it Art or hap,
He hath spoken true. The very Dice obey him,
And in our sports my better cunning faints,
Vnder his chance, if we draw lots he speeds,
His Cocks do winne the Battaile, still of mine,
When it is all to naught: and his Quailes euer
Beate mine (in hoopt) at odd's. I will to Egypte:
And though I make this marriage for my peace,
I'th'East my pleasure lies. Oh come Ventigius.
You must to Parthia, your Commissions ready:
Follow me, and reciue't.

sp.speaker: Lepidus.
sp.p:
Trouble your selues no further: pray you
hasten your Generals after.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p:
Sir, Marke Anthony, will e'ne but kisse Octauia,
and weele follow.

sp.speaker: Lepi.
sp.l: Till I shall see you in your Souldiers dresse,
Which will become you both: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Mece.
sp.p:
We shall: as I conceiue the iourney, be at
Mount before you Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Lepi.
sp.p:
Your way is shorter, my purposes do draw me
much about, you'le win two dayes vpon me.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Sir good successe.

sp.speaker: Lepi.
sp.p: Farewell.

div.head: [Act 2, Scene 5]
div.stage: Enter Cleopater, Charmian, Iras, and Alexas.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Giue me some Musicke: Musicke, moody foode
of vs that trade in Loue.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: The Musicke, hoa.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Let it alone, let's to Billiards: come Charmian.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: My arme is sore, best play with Mardian.

sp.speaker: Cleopa.
sp.p:
As well a woman with an Eunuch plaide, as
with a woman. Come you'le play with me Sir?

sp.speaker: Mardi.
sp.p: As well as I can Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: And when good will is shewed,
Though't come to short
The Actor may pleade pardon. Ile none now,
Giue me mine Angle, weele to'th'Riuer there
My Musicke playing farre off. I will betray
Tawny fine fishes, my bended hooke shall pierce
Their slimy iawes: and as I draw them vp,
Ile thinke them euery one an Anthony,
And say, ah ha; y'are caught.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
'Twas merry when you wager'd on your Ang­
ling, when your diuer did hang a salt fish on his hooke
which he with feruencie drew vp.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: That time? Oh times:
I laught him out of patience: and that night
I laught him into patience, and next morne,
Ere the ninth houre, I drunke him to his bed:
Then put my Tires and Mantles on him, whilst
I wore his Sword Phillippan. Oh from Italie,
Ramme thou thy fruitefull tidings in mine eares,
That long time haue bin barren.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Madam, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Anthonyo's dead.
If thou say so Villaine, thou kil'st thy Mistris:
But well and free, if thou so yeild him.
There is Gold, and heere
My blewest vaines to kisse: a hand that Kings
Haue lipt, and trembled kissing.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: First Madam, he is well.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Why there's more Gold.
But sirrah marke, we vse
To say, the dead are well: bring it to that,
The Gold thee, will I melt and powr
Downe thy ill vttering throate.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Good Madam heare me.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Well, go too I will:
But there's no goodnesse in thy face if Anthony
Be free and healthfull; so tart a fauour
To trumpet such good tidings. If not well,
Thou shouldst come like a Furie crown'd with Snakes,
Not like a formall man.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Wilt please you heare me?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I haue a mind to strike thee ere thou speak'st:
Yet if thou say Anthony liues, 'tis well,
Or friends with Cæsar, or not Captiue to him,
Ile set thee in a shower of Gold, and haile
Rich Pearles vpon thee.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Madam, he's well.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Well said.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: And Friends with Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Th'art an honest man.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Cæsar, and he, are greater Friends then euer.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Make thee a Fortune from me.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: But yet Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I do not like but yet, it does alay
The good precedence, fie vpon but yet,
But yet is as a Iaylor to bring foorth
Some monstrous Malefactor. Prythee Friend,
Powre out the packe of matter to mine eare,
The good and bad together: he's friends with Cæsar,
In state of health thou saist, and thou saist, free.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Free Madam, no: I made no such report,
He's bound vnto Octauia.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: For what good turne?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: For the best turne i'th'bed.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I am pale Charmian.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Madam, he's married to Octauia.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: The most infectious Pestilence vpon thee.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Good Madam patience.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What say you?
Hence horrible Villaine, or Ile spurne thine eyes
Like balls before me: Ile vnhaire thy head,
sp.stage: She hales him vp and downe.
sp.l: Thou shalt be whipt with Wyer, and stew'd in brine,
Smarting in lingring pickle.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Gratious Madam,
I that do bring the newes, made not the match.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Say 'tis not so, a Prouince I will giue thee,
And make thy Fortunes proud: the blow thou had'st
Shall make thy peace, for mouing me to rage,
And I will boot thee with what guift beside
Thy modestie can begge.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: He's married Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Rogue, thou hast liu'd too long.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Nay then Ile runne:
What meane you Madam, I haue made no fault.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Good Madam keepe your selfe within your selfe,
The man is innocent.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Some Innocents scape not the thunderbolt:
Melt Egypt into Nyle: and kindly creatures
Turne all to Serpents. Call the slaue againe,
Though I am mad, I will not byte him: Call?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: He is afeard to come.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I will not hurt him,
These hands do lacke Nobility, that they strike
A meaner then my selfe: since I my selfe
Haue giuen my selfe the cause. Come hither Sir.
Though it be honest, it is neuer good
To bring bad newes: giue to a gratious Message
An host of tongues, but let ill tydings tell
Themselues, when they be felt.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: I haue done my duty.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Is he married?
I cannot hate thee worser then I do,
If thou againe say yes.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: He's married Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: The Gods confound thee,
Dost thou hold there still?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Should I lye Madame?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Oh, I would thou didst:
So halfe my Egypt were submerg'd and made
A Cesterne for scal'd Snakes. Go get thee hence,
Had'st thou Narcissus in thy face to me,
Thou would'st appeere most vgly: He is married?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: I craue your Highnesse pardon.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: He is married?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Take no offence, that I would not offend you,
To punnish me for what you make me do
Seemes much vnequall, he's married to Octauia.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Oh that his fault should make a knaue of thee,
That art not what th'art sure of. Get thee hence,
The Marchandize which thou hast brought from Rome
Are all too deere for me:
Lye they vpon thy hand, and be vndone by em.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Good your Highnesse patience.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: In praysing Anthony, I haue disprais'd Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Many times Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I am paid for't now: lead me from hence,
I faint, oh Iras, Charmian: 'tis no matter.
Go to the Fellow, good Alexas bid him
Report the feature of Octauia: her yeares,
Her inclination, let him not leaue out
The colour of her haire. Bring me word quickly,
Let him for euer go, let him not Charmian,
Though he be painted one way like a Gorgon,
The other wayes a Mars. Bid you Alexas
Bring me word, how tall she is: pitty me Charmian,
But do not speake to me. Lead me to my Chamber.

div.head: [Act 2, Scene 6]
div.stage:
Flourish. Enter Pompey, at one doore with Drum and Trum­
pet: at another Cæsar, Lepidus, Anthony, Enobarbus, Me­
cenas, Agrippa, Menas with Souldiers Marching.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Your Hostages I haue, so haue you mine:
And we shall talke before we fight.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Most meete that first we come to words,
And therefore haue we
Our written purposes before vs sent,
Which if thou hast considered, let vs know,
If 'twill tye vp thy discontented Sword,
And carry backe to Cicelie much tall youth,
That else must perish heere.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: To you all three,
The Senators alone of this great world,
Chiefe Factors for the Gods. I do not know,
Wherefore my Father should reuengers want,
Hauing a Sonne and Friends, since Iulius Cæsar,
Who at Phillippi the good Brutus ghosted,
There saw you labouring for him. What was't
That mou'd pale Cassius to conspire? And what
Made all‑honor'd, honest, Romaine Brutus,
With the arm'd rest, Courtiers of beautious freedome,
To drench the Capitoll, but that they would
Haue one man but a man, and that his it
Hath made me rigge my Nauie. At whose burthen,
The anger'd Ocean fomes, with which I meant
To scourge th'ingratitude, that despightfull Rome
Cast on my Noble Father.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Take your time.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou can'st not feare vs Pompey with thy sailes.
Weele speake with thee at Sea. At land thou know'st
How much we do o're‑count thee.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: At Land indeed
Thou dost orecount me of my Fathers house:
But since the Cuckoo buildes not for himselfe,
Remaine in't as thou maist.

sp.speaker: Lepi.
sp.l: Be pleas'd to tell vs,
(For this is from the present how you take)
The offers we haue sent you.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: There's the point.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Which do not be entreated too,
But waigh what it is worth imbrac'd

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: And what may follow to try a larger Fortune.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: You haue made me offer
Of Cicelie, Sardinia: and I must
Rid all the Sea of Pirats. Then, to send
Measures of Wheate to Rome: this greed vpon,
To part with vnhackt edges, and beare backe
Our Targes vndinted.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: That's our offer.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Know then I came before you heere,
A man prepar'd
To take this offer. But Marke Anthony,
Put me to some impatience: though I loose
The praise of it by telling. You must know
When Cæsar and your Brother were at blowes,
Your Mother came to Cicelie, and did finde
Her welcome Friendly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I haue heard it Pompey,
And am well studied for a liberall thanks,
Which I do owe you.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Let me haue your hand:
I did not thinke Sir, to haue met you heere,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The beds i'th'East are soft, and thanks to you,
That cal'd me timelier then my purpose hither:
For I haue gained by't.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Since I saw you last, ther's a change vpon you.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Well, I know not,
What counts harsh Fortune cast's vpon my face,
But in my bosome shall she neuer come,
To make my heart her vassaile.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Well met heere.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: I hope so Lepidus, thus we are agreed:
I craue our composion may be written
And seal'd betweene vs,

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: That's the next to do.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Weele feast each other, ere we part, and lett's
Draw lots who shall begin.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That will I Pompey.

sp.speaker: Pompey.
sp.p:
No Anthony take the lot: but first or last,
your fine Egyptian cookerie shall haue the fame, I haue
heard that Iulius Cæsar, grew fat with feasting there.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: You haue heard much.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: I haue faire meaning Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And faire words to them.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Then so much haue I heard,
And I haue heard Appolodorus carried⸺

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: No more that: he did so.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: What I pray you?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: A certaine Queene to Cæsar in a Matris.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: I know thee now, how far'st thou Souldier?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Well, and well am like to do, for I perceiue
Foure Feasts are toward.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Let me shake thy hand,
I neuer hated thee: I haue seene thee fight,
When I haue enuied thy behauiour.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: Sir, I neuer lou'd you much, but I ha' prais'd ye,
When you haue well deseru'd ten times as much,
As I haue said you did.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Inioy thy plainnesse,
It nothing ill becomes thee:
Aboord my Gally, I inuite you all.
Will you leade Lords?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Shew's the way, sir.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Come.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
Thy Father Pompey would ne're haue made this
Treaty. You, and I haue knowne sir.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: At Sea, I thinke.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: We haue Sir.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: You haue done well by water.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: And you by Land.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
I will praise any man that will praise me, thogh
it cannot be denied what I haue done by Land.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Nor what I haue done by water.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
Yes some‑thing you can deny for your owne
safety: you haue bin a great Theefe by Sea.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: And you by Land.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
There I deny my Land seruice: but giue mee
your hand Menas, if our eyes had authority, heere they
might take two Theeues kissing.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
All mens faces are true, whatsomere their hands
are.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
But there is neuer a fayre Woman, ha's a true
Face.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No slander, they steale hearts.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p: We came hither to fight with you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
For my part, I am sorry it is turn'd to a Drink­
ing. Pompey doth this day laugh away his Fortune.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p: If he do, sure he cannot weep't backe againe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
Y'haue said Sir, we look'd not for Marke An­
thony heere, pray you, is he married to Cleopatra?

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p: Cæsars Sister is call'd Octauia.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: True Sir, she was the wife of Caius Marcellus.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p: But she is now the wife of Marcus Anthonius.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Pray'ye sir.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Then is Cæsar and he, for euer knit together.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
If I were bound to Diuine of this vnity, I wold
not Prophesie so.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
I thinke the policy of that purpose, made more
in the Marriage, then the loue of the parties.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
I thinke so too. But you shall finde the band
that seemes to tye their friendship together, will bee the
very strangler of their Amity: Octauia is of a holy, cold,
and still conuersation.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Who would not haue his wife so?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Not he that himselfe is not so: which is Marke
Anthony: he will to his Egyptian dish againe: then shall
the sighes of Octauia blow the fire vp in Cæsar, and (as I
said before) that which is the strength of their Amity,
shall proue the immediate Author of their variance. An­
thony will vse his affection where it is. Hee married but
his occasion here.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
And thus it may be. Come Sir, will you aboord?
I haue a health for you.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
I shall take it sir: we haue vs'd our Throats in
Egypt.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Come, let's away.

div.head: [Act 2, Scene 7]
div.stage: Enter two or three Seruants with a Banket.

sp.p:
Heere they'l be man: some o'th'their Plants are ill
rooted already, the least winde i'th'world wil blow them
downe.
Lepidus is high Conlord.
They haue made him drinke Almes drinke.

As they pinch one another by the disposition, hee
cries out, no more; reconciles them to his entreatie, and
himselfe to'th'drinke.

But it raises the greater warre betweene him & his
discretion.

Why this it is to haue a name in great mens Fel­
lowship: I had as liue haue a Reede that will doe me no
seruice, as a Partizan I could not heaue.

To be call'd into a huge Sphere, and not to be seene
to moue in't, are the holes where eyes should bee, which
pittifully disaster the cheekes.

div.stage:
Enter Cæsar, Anthony, Pompey, Lepidus, Agrippa, Mecenas,
Enobarbus, Menes, with other Captaines.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thus do they Sir: they take the flow o'th'Nyle
By certaine scales i'th'Pyramid: they know
By'th'height, the lownesse, or the meane: If dearth
Or Foizon follow. The higher Nilus swels,
The more it promises: as it ebbes, the Seedsman
Vpon the slime and Ooze scatters his graine,
And shortly comes to Haruest.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Y'haue strange Serpents there?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Your Serpent of Egypt, is bred now of your mud
by the operation of your Sun: so is your Crocodile.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: They are so.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Sit, and some Wine: A health to Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: I am not so well as I should be:
But Ile ne're out.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
Not till you haue slept: I feare me you'l bee in
till then.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Nay certainly, I haue heard the Ptolomies Pyra­
misis are very goodly things: without contradiction I
haue heard that.

sp.speaker: Menas.
sp.l: Pompey, a word.

sp.speaker: Pomp.
sp.p: Say in mine eare, what is't.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Forsake thy seate I do beseech thee Captaine,
And heare me speake a word.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Forbeare me till anon.
This Wine for Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: What manner o'thing is your Crocodile?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
It is shap'd sir like it selfe, and it is as broad as it
hath bredth; It is iust so high as it is, and mooues with it
owne organs. It liues by that which nourisheth it, and
the Elements once out of it, it Transmigrates.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: What colour is it of?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Of it owne colour too.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: 'Tis a strange Serpent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis so, and the teares of it are wet.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Will this description satisfie him?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
With the Health that Pompey giues him, else he
is a very Epicure.

sp.speaker: Pomp.
sp.l: Go hang sir, hang: tell me of that? Away:
Do as I bid you. Where's this Cup I call'd for?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: If for the sake of Merit thou wilt heare mee,
Rise from thy stoole.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: I thinke th'art mad: the matter?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I haue euer held my cap off to thy Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Thou hast seru'd me with much faith: what's
else to say? Be iolly Lords.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: These Quicke‑sands Lepidus,
Keepe off, them for you sinke.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Wilt thou be Lord of all the world?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: What saist thou?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Wilt thou be Lord of the whole world?
That's twice.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: How should that be?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
But entertaine it, and though thou thinke me
poore, I am the man will giue thee all the world.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Hast thou drunke well.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: No Pompey, I haue kept me from the cup,
Thou art if thou dar'st be, the earthly Ioue:
What ere the Ocean pales, or skie inclippes,
Is thine, if thou wilt ha't.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Shew me which way?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: These three World‑sharers, these Competitors
Are in thy vessell. Let me cut the Cable,
And when we are put off, fall to their throates:
All there is thine.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Ah, this thou shouldst haue done,
And not haue spoke on't. In me 'tis villanie,
In thee, 't had bin good seruice: thou must know,
'Tis not my profit that does lead mine Honour:
Mine Honour it, Repent that ere thy tongue,
Hath so betraide thine acte. Being done vnknowne,
I should haue found it afterwards well done,
But must condemne it now: desist, and drinke.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: For this, Ile neuer follow
Thy paul'd Fortunes more,
Who seekes and will not take, when once 'tis offer'd,
Shall neuer finde it more.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: This health to Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Beare him ashore,
Ile pledge it for him Pompey.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Heere's to thee Menas.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Enobarbus, welcome.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Fill till the cup be hid.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: There's a strong Fellow Menas.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
A beares the third part of the world man: seest
not?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
The third part, then he is drunk: would it were
all, that it might go on wheeles.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Drinke thou: encrease the Reeles.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Come.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: This is not yet an Alexandrian Feast.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It ripen's towards it: strike the Vessells hoa.
Heere's to Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.p:
I could well forbear't, it's monstrous labour
when I wash my braine, and it grow fouler.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Be a Child o'th'time.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.p:
Possesse it, Ile make answer: but I had rather
fast from all, foure dayes, then drinke so much in one.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
Ha my braue Emperour, shall we daunce now
the Egyptian Backenals, and celebrate our drinke?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Let's ha't good Souldier.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come, let's all take hands,
Till that the conquering Wine hath steep't our sense,
In soft and delicate Lethe.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: All take hands:
Make battery to our eares with the loud Musicke,
The while, Ile place you, then the Boy shall sing.
The holding euery man shall beate as loud,
As his strong sides can volly.
sp.stage: Musicke Playes. Enobarbus places them hand in hand.
sp.l: Come thou Monarch of the Vine,
Plumpie Bacchus, with pinke eyne:
In thy Fattes our Cares be drown'd,
With thy Grapes our haires be Crown'd.
Cup vs till the world go round,
Cup vs till the world go round.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: What would you more?
Pompey goodnight. Good Brother
Let me request you of our grauer businesse
Frownes at this leuitie. Gentle Lords let's part,
You see we haue burnt our cheekes. Strong Enobarbe
Is weaker then the Wine, and mine owne tongue
Spleet's what it speakes: the wilde disguise hath almost
Antickt vs all. What needs more words? goodnight.
Good Anthony your hand.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Ile try you on the shore.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: And shall Sir, giues your hand.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Oh Anthony, you haue my Father house.
But what, we are Friends?
Come downe into the Boate.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Take heed you fall not Menas: Ile not on shore,
No to my Cabin: these Drummes,
These Trumpets, Flutes: what
Let Neptune heare, we bid aloud farewell
To these great Fellowes. Sound and be hang'd, sound out.

sp.speaker: Enor.
sp.l: Hoo saies a there's my Cap.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Hoa, Noble Captaine, come.

div.head: [Act 3, Scene 1]
div.stage:
Enter Ventidius as it were in triumph, the dead body of Paco­
rus borne before him.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Now darting Parthya art thou stroke, and now
Pleas'd Fortune does of Marcus Crassus death
Make me reuenger. Beare the Kings Sonnes body,
Before our Army thy Pacorus Orades,
Paies this for Marcus Crassus.

sp.speaker: Romaine.
sp.l: Noble Ventidius,
Whil'st yet with Parthian blood thy Sword is warme,
The Fugitiue Parthians follow. Spurre through Media,
Mesapotamia, and the shelters, whether
The routed flie. So thy grand Captaine Anthony
Shall set thee on triumphant Chariots, and
Put Garlands on thy head.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Oh Sillius, Sillius,
I haue done enough. A lower place note well
May make too great an act. For learne this Sillius,
Better to leaue vndone, then by our deed
Acquire too high a Fame, when him we serues away.
Cæsar and Anthony, haue euer wonne
More in their officer, then person. Sossius
One of my place in Syria, his Lieutenant,
For quicke accumulation of renowne,
Which he atchiu'd by'th'minute, lost his fauour.
Who does i'th'Warres more then his Captaine can,
Becomes his Captaines Captaine: and Ambition
(The Souldiers vertue) rather makes choise of losse
Then gaine, which darkens him.
I could do more to do Anthonius good,
But 'twould offend him. And in his offence,
Should my performance perish.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p:
Thou hast Ventidius that, without the which a
Souldier and his Sword graunts scarce distinction: thou
wilt write to Anthony.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Ile humbly signifie what in his name,
That magicall word of Warre we haue effected,
How with his Banners, and his well paid ranks,
The nere‑yet beaten Horse of Parthia,
We haue iaded out o'th'Field.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Where is he now?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: He purposeth to Athens, whither with what hast
The waight we must conuay with's, will permit:
We shall appeare before him. On there, passe along.

div.head: [Act 3, Scene 2]
div.stage: Enter Agrippa at one doore, Enobarbus at another.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: What are the Brothers parted?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: They haue dispatcht with Pompey, he is gone,
The other three are Sealing. Octauia weepes
To part from Rome: Cæsar is sad, and Lepidus
Since Pompey's feast, as Menas saies, is troubled
With the Greene‑Sicknesse.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: 'Tis a Noble Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: A very fine one: oh, how he loues Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Nay but how deerely he adores Mark Anthony.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Cæsar? why he's the Iupiter of men.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What's Anthony, the God of Iupiter?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Spake you of Cæsar? How, the non‑pareill?

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Oh Anthony, oh thou Arabian Bird!

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Would you praise Cæsar, say Cæsar go no further.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.l: Indeed he plied them both with excellent praises.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: But he loues Cæsar best, yet he loues Anthony:
Hoo, Hearts, Tongues, Figure,
Scribes, Bards, Poets, cannot
Thinke speake, cast, write, sing, number: hoo,
His loue to Anthony. But as for Cæsar,
Kneele downe, kneele downe, and wonder.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Both he loues.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: They are his Shards, and he their Beetle, so:
This is to horse: Adieu, Noble Agrippa.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Good Fortune worthy Souldier, and farewell.

div.stage: Enter Cæsar, Anthony, Lepidus, and Octauia.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: No further Sir.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: You take from me a great part of my selfe:
Vse me well in't. Sister, proue such a wife
As my thoughts make thee, and as my farthest Band
Shall passe on thy approofe: most Noble Anthony,
Let not the peece of Vertue which is set
Betwixt vs, as the Cyment of our loue
To keepe it builded, be the Ramme to batter
The Fortresse of it: for better might we
Haue lou'd without this meane, if on both parts
This be not cherisht.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Make me not offended, in your distrust.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: I haue said.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You shall not finde,
Though you be therein curious, the lest cause
For what you seeme to feare, so the Gods keepe you,
And make the hearts of Romaines serue your ends:
We will heere part.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Farewell my deerest Sister, fare thee well,
The Elements be kind to thee, and make
Thy spirits all of comfort: fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: My Noble Brother.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: The Aprill's in her eyes, it is Loues spring,
And these the showers to bring it on: be cheerfull.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Sir, looke well to my Husbands house: and—

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: What Octauia?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Ile tell you in your eare.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Her tongue will not obey her heart, nor can
Her heart informe her tongue.
The Swannes downe feather
That stands vpon the Swell at the full of Tide:
And neither way inclines.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Will Cæsar weepe?

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.l: He ha's a cloud in's face.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
He were the worse for that were he a Horse, so is
he being aman.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Why Enobarbus:
When Anthony found Iulius Cæsar dead,
He cried almost to roaring: And he wept,
When at Phillippi he found Brutus slaine.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: That year indeed, he was trobled with a rheume,
What willingly he did confound, he wail'd,
Beleeu't till I weepe too.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: No sweet Octauia,
You shall heare from me still: the time shall not
Out‑go my thinking on you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come Sir, come,
Ile wrastle with you in my strength of loue,
Looke heere I haue you, thus I let you go,
And giue you to the Gods.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Adieu, be happy.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Let all the number of the Starres giue light
To thy faire way.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Farewell, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Farewell.

div.head: [Act 3, Scene 3]
div.stage: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Iras, and Alexas.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Where is the Fellow?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Halfe afeard to come.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Go too, go too: Come hither Sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Good Maiestie: Herod of Iury dare not looke
vpon you, but when you are well pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
That Herods head, Ile haue: but how? When
Anthony is gone, through whom I might commaund it:
Come thou neere.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Most gratious Maiestie.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Did'st thou behold Octauia?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: I dread Queene.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p:
Madam in Rome, I lookt her in the face: and
saw her led betweene her Brother, and Marke Anthony.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Is she as tall as me?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: She is not Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Didst heare her speake?
Is she shrill tongu'd or low?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Madam, I heard her speake, she is low voic'd.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: That's not so good: he cannot like her long.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Like her? Oh Isis: 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I thinke so Charmian: dull of tongue, & dwarfish
What Maiestie is in her gate, remember
If ere thou look'st on Maiestie.
sp.note: There is a large ink mark at the far right side of this line.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: She creepes: her motion, & her station are as one:
She shewes a body, rather then a life,
